Lily Ross Taylor
already been warned by Bibulus to be on his guard The young Curio,  not yet a member of the senate,  was called in,  and he pointed out that Paulus was in Macedonia at the time the plot was to have been carried out.  The senate voted that Vettius should be thrown into chains,  and the whole matter was immediately reported to the people in a public meeting.  The next day Caesar called another public meeting and brought Vettius to the rostra.  Cicero was sure that Vettius had been coached meanwhile.  The informer first withdrew the accusation against Brutus,  and the withdrawal was attributed by Cicero to a nocturna deprecatio ( of course from Brutus' mother,  whose relations with Caesar were a subject of sip ).  It is doubtful whether Vettius included Paulus ( who had an alibi ) in his list this time,  but he mentioned several new names — L.  Lucullus,  C.  Fannius,  L.  Domitius Ahenobarbus ; there was even a vague reference to Cicero himself.  After the meeting was dissolved Vettius,  recalled to the rostra by the tribune Vatinius,  added two other names,  luventius and Cicero's son - in - law Piso.  Cicero thought that Vettius would be tried for violence,  and that after he was condemned there would be a special tigation at which Vettius would turn state's evidence.  If we can believe Cicero's later statement ( in Vdtin.  26 ),  Vatinius actually presented a bill calling for the investigation.  I should judge from the passage already quoted from the pro Flacco that the bill was under consideration when that oration was delivered — in August,  according to my dating.  But in the end the investigation was dropped and Vettius was strangled in prison. 
The Vettius affair was so badly bungled that some admirers of sar's political genius have accepted Cicero's account in the In Vatinium ( 24—26 ) and have attributed the mistakes to Vatinius But in that tion Cicero was doing all he could both to blacken his opponent and to spare Caesar.  Cicero's letter written immediately after the event proves to my mind that Caesar must bear the brunt of the responsibility both for trying to implicate Curio in a plot against Pompey and for the inept handling of the situation that developed.  Caesar did not expect Curio to reveal Vettius' overtures,  and apparently did not have a chance to coach Vettius before he was called to the senate.  It looks as if Vettius had been confused by Curio.  Caesar did not improve the situation by having tius make a different set of accusations before the people ; nor did the abortive plans for an investigation and the subsequent murder of Vettius make the whole affaire more savory. 
14.  On the date of this warning L.  A.  Constans' emendation ( op.  cit,  241 ) of the corrupt text of ad Att.  II 24,  2 to read a.  d.  Ill eins diet ( mss.  reading a.  d.  Ill Id.  diei ) seems not unlikely. 
15.  Carcopino's view that Curio was an agent provocateur of Caesar in this affair makes the bungling,  to my mind,  even harder to explain.  See his César,  Histoire romaine II ( Paris,  1936 ) 690 ff.
